docs.title: PowerShell Preworkout (PSPreworkout)
docs.text: A special mix of tools to help jump start your PowerShell session!

docs.title: Inspiration
docs.text:
Why PSPreworkout? Whether you are developing PowerShell code or performing daily tasks, the goal of PSPreworkout is to start working efficiently as quickly as possible. The idea for the name was inspired by the pre-workout mix that I sometimes drink for an extra kick of energy and focus before working out.

The PSPreworkout module contains shortcuts for setting up a PowerShell environment, configuring Git, customizing the shell, working with environment variables, creating new script files from a template, updating packages, and more!

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
Install-Module -Name PSPreworkout -Scope CurrentUser
Get-Command -Module PSPreworkout

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text: Please feel free submit an issue or a PR to report bugs, suggest improvements, or add new ideas to the module!

docs.title: Presentations
docs.text: • PSPreworkout Module Walkthrough at the PowerShell Usergroup Inn-Salzach - Thanks to the Inn-Salzach PowerShell User Group for inviting me to share my first public presentation!

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Get a filtered and de-duplicated list of commands from your history.

docs.title: BasicFilter (Default)
docs.text: Get-CommandHistory [-Exclude <string[]>] [-Filter <string[]>] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: NoFilter
docs.text: Get-CommandHistory [-All] [-Exclude <string[]>] [-Filter <string[]>] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: ALIASES
docs.text: This cmdlet has the following aliases, {{Insert list of aliases}}

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: This function filters the output of Get-History to exclude a list of ignored commands and any commands that are less than 4 characters long. It can also be used to find all commands that match a given pattern. It is useful for quickly finding things from your history that you want to document or re-invoke.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Get-CommandHistory -Filter ‘Disk’

This will return all commands from your history that contain the word ‘Disk’.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text:
Get-CommandHistory -Exclude ‘Get-Service’, ‘Get-Process’

This will return all commands from your history that do not contain the words ‘Get-Service’ or ‘Get-Process’ (while also still filtering out the default ignore list).

docs.title: EXAMPLE 3
docs.text:
Get-CommandHistory -All

This will return all commands from your history without any filtering.

docs.title: -All
docs.text:
Show all command history without filtering anything out.

Type: System.Management.Automation.SwitchParameter
DefaultValue: False
SupportsWildcards: false
Aliases: []
ParameterSets:
- Name: NoFilter
  Position: Named
  IsRequired: false
  ValueFromPipeline: false
  ValueFromPipelineByPropertyName: false
  ValueFromRemainingArguments: false
DontShow: false
AcceptedValues: []
HelpMessage: ''

docs.title: -Exclude
docs.text:
A string or array of strings to exclude. Commands that have these words in them will be excluded from the history output. The default ignored commands are: Get-History, Invoke-CommandHistory, Get-CommandHistory, clear.

Type: System.String[]
DefaultValue: ''
SupportsWildcards: false
Aliases: []
ParameterSets:
- Name: (All)
  Position: Named
  IsRequired: false
  ValueFromPipeline: false
  ValueFromPipelineByPropertyName: false
  ValueFromRemainingArguments: false
DontShow: false
AcceptedValues: []
HelpMessage: ''

docs.title: -Filter
docs.text:
A string or regex pattern to find in the command history. Commands that contain this pattern will be returned.

The Filter is passed to the -match operator, so it can be a simple string or a more complex regex pattern.

Type: System.String[]
DefaultValue: ''
SupportsWildcards: false
Aliases: []
ParameterSets:
- Name: (All)
  Position: Named
  IsRequired: false
  ValueFromPipeline: false
  ValueFromPipelineByPropertyName: false
  ValueFromRemainingArguments: false
DontShow: false
AcceptedValues: []
HelpMessage: ''

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Retrieves the value of an environment variable.

docs.title: LookupByName (Default)
docs.text:
Get-EnvironmentVariable [[-Name] <string>] [-Target <EnvironmentVariableTarget[]>] [-All]
 [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: LookupByRegexPattern
docs.text:
Get-EnvironmentVariable [[-Pattern] <string>] [-Target <EnvironmentVariableTarget[]>] [-All]
 [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: ALIASES
docs.text: This cmdlet has the following aliases, {{Insert list of aliases}}

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: The Get-EnvironmentVariable function retrieves the value of the specified environment variable or displays all environment variables. It is capable of finding variables by an exact name match or by using a regex pattern match. It can retrieve environment variables from the process, machine, and user targets. If no parameters are specified, all environment variables are returned from all targets.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Get-EnvironmentVariable -Name ‘UserName’ -Target ‘User’

Retrieves the value of the “UserName” environment variable from the process target.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text:
Get-EnvironmentVariable -Name ‘Path’ -Target ‘Machine’

Retrieves the value of the PATH environment variable from the machine target.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 3
docs.text:
Get-EnvironmentVariable -Pattern ‘^u’

Get environment variables with names that begin with the letter “u” in any target.

docs.title: -All
docs.text:
Optionally get all environment variables from all targets or all environment variables from one specified target. Process ID and process name will be included for process environment variables.

Type: System.Management.Automation.SwitchParameter
DefaultValue: False
SupportsWildcards: false
Aliases: []
ParameterSets:
- Name: LookupByRegexPattern

- Name: LookupByName

  ValueFromRemainingArguments: false
DontShow: false
AcceptedValues: []
HelpMessage: ''

The name of the environment variable to retrieve.

docs.title: CommonParameters
docs.text: This cmdlet supports the common parameters: -Debug, -ErrorAction, -ErrorVariable, -InformationAction, -InformationVariable, -OutBuffer, -OutVariable, -PipelineVariable, -ProgressAction, -Verbose, -WarningAction, and -WarningVariable. For more information, see about_CommonParameters.

docs.title: System.Object
docs.text: {{ Fill in the Description }}

docs.title: NOTES
docs.text:
Author: Sam Erde Version: 1.0.0 Modified: 2025/03/05

About Environment Variables:

Variable names are case-sensitive on Linux and macOS, but not on Windows. PowerShell is case-insensitive by default and compensates for case-sensitivity on Linux and macOS. To make PowerShell case-sensitive, use the -CaseSensitive parameter when starting PowerShell.

Why is ‘Target’ used by .NET instead of the familiar ‘Scope’ parameter name? @IISResetMe (Mathias R. Jessen) explains: “Scope” would imply some sort of integrated hierarchy of env variables - that’s not really the case. Target=Process translates to kernel32!GetEnvironmentVariable (which then in turn reads the PEB from the calling process), whereas Target={User,Machine} causes a registry lookup against environment data in either HKCU or HKLM.

The relevant sources for the User and Machine targets are in the registry at: - HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Environment - HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Session Manager\Environment

See more at https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.core/about/about_environment_variables.

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Get the object type of each value in a hashtable.

docs.title: __AllParameterSets
docs.text: Get-HashtableValueType [-Hashtable] <hashtable> [-Key <string>] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: ALIASES
docs.text: This cmdlet has the following aliases, {{Insert list of aliases}}

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: This function retrieves the object type information of each value in a hashtable and returns System.Reflection.TypeInfo objects with additional ItemKey properties for identification. Results can be filtered to a specific key using the Key parameter.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Get-HashtableValueType -Hashtable @{ Key1 = 123; Key2 = “Hello”; Key3 = @(1, 2, 3) }

Returns type information for all keys in the hashtable, sorted by key name.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text:
Get-HashtableValueType -Hashtable @{ Key1 = 123; Key2 = “Hello”; Key3 = @(1, 2, 3) } -Key “Key2”

Returns type information only for the “Key2” entry (System.String).

docs.title: EXAMPLE 3
docs.text:
@{ Name = “John”; Age = 30; Active = $true } | Get-HashtableValueType

Demonstrates pipeline input usage to analyze hashtable value types.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 4
docs.text:
$config = @{ “Server Name” = “web01”; Port = 8080; SSL = $true } Get-HashtableValueType $config -Key

Shows tab completion for keys, including proper quoting for keys with spaces.

docs.title: -Hashtable
docs.text:
The hashtable to inspect.

Type: System.Collections.Hashtable
DefaultValue: ''
SupportsWildcards: false
Aliases: []
ParameterSets:
- Name: (All)
  Position: 0
  IsRequired: true
  ValueFromPipeline: true
  ValueFromPipelineByPropertyName: false
  ValueFromRemainingArguments: false
DontShow: false
AcceptedValues: []
HelpMessage: ''

docs.title: -Key
docs.text:
Optional. Specify a specific hashtable key to get the type information for only that key’s value. If not specified, type information for all keys will be returned. Tab completion is available for this parameter based on the keys in the provided hashtable.

Type: System.String
DefaultValue: ''
SupportsWildcards: false
Aliases: []
ParameterSets:
- Name: (All)
  Position: Named
  IsRequired: false
  ValueFromPipeline: false
  ValueFromPipelineByPropertyName: false
  ValueFromRemainingArguments: false
DontShow: false
AcceptedValues: []
HelpMessage: ''

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Get a list of installed PowerShell modules that have updates available in their source repository.

docs.title: __AllParameterSets
docs.text: Get-ModulesWithUpdate [[-Name] <List`1[string]>] [-PassThru] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: ALIASES
docs.text: This cmdlet has the following aliases, {{Insert list of aliases}}

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text:
This function retrieves a list of installed PowerShell modules and checks for updates available in their source repository (e.g.: PowerShell Gallery or MAR).

If a pre-release version is installed, it checks the repository for a newer pre-release version or an equivalent (or higher) stable version. Otherwise, it only checks for stable updates.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text: Get-ModulesWithUpdate This command retrieves all installed PowerShell modules and checks for updates in their source repository.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text: Get-ModulesWithUpdate -PassThru This command checks all installed modules for updates. It returns PSModuleInfo objects to the pipeline and displays console output about available updates.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 3
docs.text: Get-ModulesWithUpdate -Name ‘Pester’, ‘PSScriptAnalyzer’ -PassThru | Update-PSResource This command checks specific modules for updates, displays console output about available updates, and pipes the results to Update-PSResource.

docs.title: -Name
docs.text:
The module name or list of module names to check for updates. Wildcards and arrays are allowed. All modules (‘*’) are checked by default.

Type: System.Collections.Generic.List`1[System.String]
DefaultValue: "@('*')"
SupportsWildcards: true
Aliases: []
ParameterSets:
- Name: (All)
  Position: 0
  IsRequired: false
  ValueFromPipeline: true
  ValueFromPipelineByPropertyName: true
  ValueFromRemainingArguments: false
DontShow: false
AcceptedValues: []
HelpMessage: ''

docs.title: -PassThru
docs.text:
Display console output while returning module objects to the pipeline. When specified, the function will show available updates in the console and also return module objects for further processing.

Type: System.Management.Automation.SwitchParameter
DefaultValue: False
SupportsWildcards: false
Aliases: []
ParameterSets:
- Name: (All)
  Position: Named
  IsRequired: false
  ValueFromPipeline: false
  ValueFromPipelineByPropertyName: false
  ValueFromRemainingArguments: false
DontShow: false
AcceptedValues: []
HelpMessage: ''

docs.title: CommonParameters
docs.text: This cmdlet supports the common parameters: -Debug, -ErrorAction, -ErrorVariable, -InformationAction, -InformationVariable, -OutBuffer, -OutVariable, -PipelineVariable, -ProgressAction, -Verbose, -WarningAction, and -WarningVariable. For more information, see about_CommonParameters.

docs.title: System.Collections.Generic.List`1[[System.String, System.Private.CoreLib, Version=9.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=7cec85d7bea7798e]]
docs.text: {{ Fill in the Description }}

docs.title: System.Management.Automation.PSObject
docs.text: {{ Fill in the Description }}

docs.title: NOTES
docs.text:
This function uses Microsoft.PowerShell.PSResourceGet cmdlets for improved performance and functionality over the PowerShellGet module’s cmdlets. The required module will be automatically installed if not present.

Scope Priority: The function prioritizes CurrentUser scope modules over AllUsers scope modules, which matches PowerShell’s own behavior for importing or updating modules. When a module is installed in both scopes, it checks for updates against the CurrentUser version since that’s what PowerShell would load by default. Use -Verbose to see which version and scope is being used for each module.

To Do: - Batch and “paginate” online checks to speed up. Find-PSResource can return multiple results in one request. - Add parameter for specifying specific repositories to check.

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Download a portable version of PowerShell to run anywhere on demand.

docs.title: __AllParameterSets
docs.text: Get-PowerShellPortable [[-Path] <string>] [-Extract] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: ALIASES
docs.text: This cmdlet has the following aliases, {{Insert list of aliases}}

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: This function helps you download a zipped copy of the latest version of PowerShell that can be run without needing to install it.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Get-PowerShellPortable -Path $HOME -Extract

Download the latest ZIP/TAR of PowerShell to your $HOME folder. It will be extracted into a folder that matches the filename of the compressed archive.

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Initialize configuration your PowerShell environment and git.

docs.title: __AllParameterSets
docs.text:
Initialize-PSEnvironmentConfiguration [-Name] <string> [-Email] <string> [[-Font] <string>]
 [[-Packages] <string[]>] [[-Modules] <string[]>] [-SkipPackages] [-SkipModules]
 [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: ALIASES
docs.text: This cmdlet has the following aliases, {{Insert list of aliases}}

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: Install supporting packages, configure git, and set your console font with this function.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Initialize the PowerShell working environment with a custom font, and set my name and email address for Git commits.

Initialize-PSEnvironmentConfiguration -Name ‘Sam Erde’ -Email ‘sam@example.local’ -ConsoleFont ‘FiraCode Nerd Font’

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Install and setup the WinGetCommandNotFound utility from Microsoft PowerToys.

docs.title: __AllParameterSets
docs.text: Install-CommandNotFoundUtility [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: ALIASES

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Install Oh My Posh and add it to your profile.

docs.title: Font
docs.text:
Install-OhMyPosh [-WingetSource <string>] [-Method <string>] [-InstallNerdFont] [-Font <string>]
 [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: ALIASES
docs.text: This cmdlet has the following aliases, {{Insert list of aliases}}

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: An over-engineered script to install Oh My Posh. This script exists as an exercise and is not intended for production use.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text: Install-OhMyPosh

docs.title: -Font
docs.text:
Choose a nerd font to install.

  • Default - Installs “Meslo” as the default nerd font.
  • Select - Lets you choose a nerd font from the list.

DefaultValue: Default
SupportsWildcards: false

- Name: Font
  Position: Named

  ValueFromPipelineByPropertyName: false
  ValueFromRemainingArguments: false
DontShow: false
AcceptedValues: []
HelpMessage: ''

  ValueFromRemainingArguments: false

  • direct (default)

SupportsWildcards: false

  ValueFromRemainingArguments: false
DontShow: false

HelpMessage: ''

Specify which source to install from.

- winget  - Install from winget (default).
- msstore - Install from the Microsoft Store.

DefaultValue: winget

  ValueFromRemainingArguments: false
DontShow: false
AcceptedValues: []
HelpMessage: ''

docs.title: __AllParameterSets
docs.text: Install-PowerShellISE [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: ALIASES
docs.text: This cmdlet has the following aliases, {{Insert list of aliases}}

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: This script installs Windows PowerShell ISE if it was not installed or previously removed. It includes a step that temporarily resets the Windows Automatic Update server source in the registry, which may resolve errors that some systems experience while trying to add Windows Capabilities.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text: Install-PowerShellISE

docs.title: RELATED LINKS
docs.text: {{ Fill in the related links here }}

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This document describes the automated solution for keeping the MkDocs navigation synchronized with the PowerShell module’s exported functions.

docs.title: Problem Statement
docs.text:
Previously, the nav section in mkdocs.yml had to be manually maintained whenever new functions were added to the module. This led to:

  • Missing functions in documentation navigation
  • Duplicate entries
  • Typos in file paths
  • Inconsistent organization

docs.title: Solution
docs.text:
An automated system that:

  1. Reads the FunctionsToExport from the module manifest (PSPreworkout.psd1)
  2. Filters out aliases to include only actual functions
  3. Categorizes functions into three logical groups
  4. Updates the mkdocs.yml navigation section automatically
  5. Triggers whenever the module manifest is updated on the main branch

docs.title: 1. PowerShell Script (Scripts/Update-MkDocsNavigation.ps1)
docs.text:
Purpose: Updates the navigation section in mkdocs.yml based on the module manifest.

Key Functions:

  • Get-FunctionCategory: Determines which category a function belongs to
  • Get-CategorizedFunctions: Reads and categorizes all exported functions
  • New-NavigationYaml: Generates the YAML structure for the nav section
  • Update-MkDocsYaml: Updates the mkdocs.yml file while preserving other content

Function Categories:

  • Customize: Functions for configuring PowerShell environment
  • Initialize-PSEnvironmentConfiguration
  • Install-* cmdlets
  • Set-* cmdlets
  • Edit-* cmdlets for environment files
  • Develop: Functions for PowerShell development tasks
  • New-ScriptFromTemplate
  • Get-TypeAccelerator
  • Get-LoadedAssembly

  • Show-LoadedAssembly

  • Daily Functions: General utility functions for daily operations

  • All other functions (Get-, Test-, Update-, Out-, Show-*)

docs.title: 2. GitHub Actions Workflow (.github/workflows/Update MkDocs Navigation.yml)
docs.text:
Triggers:

  • Push to main branch with changes to src/PSPreworkout/PSPreworkout.psd1
  • Manual workflow dispatch

Steps:

  1. Checkout repository
  2. Run Update-MkDocsNavigation.ps1
  3. Check if mkdocs.yml was modified
  4. Commit and push changes if mkdocs.yml was updated

Permissions:

  • contents: write - to commit changes
  • pull-requests: write - for PR operations if needed

docs.title: 3. Pester Tests (src/Tests/Unit/Update-MkDocsNavigation.Tests.ps1)
docs.text:
Test Coverage:

  • Script file validation (existence, syntax, help)
  • Function categorization logic (12 tests)
  • Navigation YAML generation (7 tests)
  • Integration tests (5 tests)

Results: 27 tests passed, 0 failed

docs.title: Automatic (Recommended)
docs.text:
The workflow automatically runs when you:

  1. Update FunctionsToExport in src/PSPreworkout/PSPreworkout.psd1
  2. Push changes to the main branch
  3. The workflow updates mkdocs.yml and commits it back

docs.title: Manual
docs.text:
Run the script directly:

# From repository root
.\Scripts\Update-MkDocsNavigation.ps1

# With verbose output
.\Scripts\Update-MkDocsNavigation.ps1 -Verbose

# With custom paths
.\Scripts\Update-MkDocsNavigation.ps1 -ManifestPath "path/to/manifest.psd1" -MkDocsPath "path/to/mkdocs.yml"

docs.title: Benefits
docs.text:
1. Automation: No manual maintenance of navigation structure
  2. Consistency: Functions always appear in the same order (alphabetical within categories)
  3. Accuracy: Prevents typos, duplicates, and missing entries
  4. Time Savings: Eliminates manual updates to mkdocs.yml
  5. Documentation Quality: Ensures documentation is always in sync with code

docs.title: Adding New Functions
docs.text:
1. Add the function to src/PSPreworkout/Public/
  2. Add the function name to FunctionsToExport in the manifest
  3. Push to main branch
  4. The workflow automatically updates mkdocs.yml

docs.title: Modifying Categories
docs.text:
To change which category a function belongs to:

  1. Edit the Get-FunctionCategory function in Scripts/Update-MkDocsNavigation.ps1
  2. Update the $developFunctions or $customizeFunctions arrays
  3. Run the script manually or push changes to trigger the workflow

docs.title: Testing Changes
docs.text:
# Run the Pester tests
Import-Module Pester
Invoke-Pester -Path ./src/Tests/Unit/Update-MkDocsNavigation.Tests.ps1

docs.title: Files Modified
docs.text:
• ✅ Scripts/Update-MkDocsNavigation.ps1 - Created
  • ✅ .github/workflows/Update MkDocs Navigation.yml - Created
  • ✅ src/Tests/Unit/Update-MkDocsNavigation.Tests.ps1 - Created
  • ✅ Scripts/README.md - Updated with documentation
  • ✅ mkdocs.yml - Fixed navigation (removed duplicates, corrected typos, added missing functions)

docs.title: Before
docs.text:
• Manual updates required
  • Had duplicate “Install-CommandNotFoundUtility” entry
  • Had typo “Install-CommandNoteFoundUtility”
  • Missing “Get-HashtableValueType” and other functions
  • “New-Credential” was listed but doesn’t exist in manifest

docs.title: After
docs.text:
• Automatic updates
  • No duplicates
  • All typos corrected
  • All exported functions included
  • Non-existent functions removed
  • Consistent alphabetical ordering

docs.title: Future Enhancements
docs.text:
Possible improvements:

  • Add metadata tags in function files to specify categories
  • Support for multiple documentation levels (beginner/advanced)
  • Auto-generate function index page
  • Support for versioned documentation

docs.title: Workflow doesn’t trigger
docs.text:
• Check that changes were pushed to main branch
  • Verify src/PSPreworkout/PSPreworkout.psd1 was modified
  • Check workflow permissions in repository settings

docs.title: Script fails locally
docs.text:
• Ensure you’re running from repository root
  • Check PowerShell version (requires 5.1+)
  • Verify manifest file exists at expected path

docs.title: Tests fail
docs.text:
• Some tests may skip if running outside the repository structure
  • Check that Pester 5.0+ is installed
  • Verify test file paths are correct

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• MkDocs Documentation
  • GitHub Actions Documentation
  • Pester Testing Framework

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Create a new advanced function from a template.

docs.title: Named
docs.text:
New-ScriptFromTemplate [-Name] <string> [-Synopsis <string>] [-Description <string>]
 [-Alias <string>] [-Author <string>] [-Path <string>] [-SkipValidation] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: VerbNoun
docs.text:
New-ScriptFromTemplate [-Verb] <string> [-Noun] <string> [-Synopsis <string>]
 [-Description <string>] [-Alias <string>] [-Author <string>] [-Path <string>] [-SkipValidation]
 [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: ALIASES
docs.text: This cmdlet has the following aliases, {{Insert list of aliases}}

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: This function creates a new function from a template and saves it to a file with the name of the function. It takes values for the function’s synopsis, description, and alias as parameters and populates comment- based help for the new function automatically.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text: New-ScriptFromTemplate -Name ‘Get-Demo’ -Synopsis ‘Get a demo.’ -Description ‘This function gets a demo.’ -Alias ‘Get-Sample’

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text: New-ScriptFromTemplate -Verb Get -Noun Something -Author ‘Sam Erde’

docs.title: -Alias
docs.text:
Optionally define an alias for the new function.

DefaultValue: ''
SupportsWildcards: false
Aliases: []

- Name: (All)
  Position: Named
  IsRequired: false
  ValueFromPipeline: false
  ValueFromPipelineByPropertyName: false
  ValueFromRemainingArguments: false
DontShow: false
AcceptedValues: []
HelpMessage: ''

Name of the author of the script. Attempts to default to the ‘FullName’ property of the currently logged in user.

HelpMessage: ''

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Convert an object to JSON and write it to a file.

docs.title: __AllParameterSets
docs.text: Out-JsonFile [-Object] <Object> [[-FilePath] <string>] [-Depth <int>] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: ALIASES
docs.text: This cmdlet has the following aliases, {{Insert list of aliases}}

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: This function converts an object to JSON and writes the output to the specified file. By default, it saves the file with the name of the object that you provided to the function.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Out-JsonFile -Object $TestObject -FilePath $HOME

Writes $TestObject as JSON to “$HOME/TestObject.json”.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text:
Out-JsonFile -Object $TestObject -FilePath C:\Temp\report.json

Writes $TestObject as JSON to C:\Temp\report.json.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 3
docs.text:
Out-JsonFile -Object $TestObject

Writes $TestObject as JSON to TestObject.json in the current working directory of the file system.

docs.title: -Depth
docs.text:
Depth to serialize the object into JSON. Default is 2.

Type: System.Int32
DefaultValue: 2
SupportsWildcards: false
Aliases: []
ParameterSets:
- Name: (All)
  Position: Named
  IsRequired: false
  ValueFromPipeline: false
  ValueFromPipelineByPropertyName: false
  ValueFromRemainingArguments: false
DontShow: false
AcceptedValues: []
HelpMessage: ''

docs.title: -FilePath
docs.text:
Full path and filename to save the JSON to. [ValidatePattern(‘.json$’)] # Do not require a JSON extension.

Type: System.String
DefaultValue: ''
SupportsWildcards: false
Aliases: []
ParameterSets:
- Name: (All)
  Position: 1
  IsRequired: false
  ValueFromPipeline: false
  ValueFromPipelineByPropertyName: false
  ValueFromRemainingArguments: false
DontShow: false
AcceptedValues: []
HelpMessage: ''

docs.title: -Object
docs.text:
The object to convert to JSON. [ValidateScript({ if (-not [string]::IsNullOrWhiteSpace($) -and -not [string]::IsNullOrEmpty($)) { $true } })]

Type: System.Object
DefaultValue: ''
SupportsWildcards: false
Aliases: []
ParameterSets:
- Name: (All)
  Position: 0
  IsRequired: true
  ValueFromPipeline: true
  ValueFromPipelineByPropertyName: false
  ValueFromRemainingArguments: false
DontShow: false
AcceptedValues: []
HelpMessage: ''

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Set the font for your consoles in Windows.

docs.title: __AllParameterSets
docs.text: Set-ConsoleFont [-Font] <string> [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: ALIASES
docs.text: This cmdlet has the following aliases, {{Insert list of aliases}}

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: Set-ConsoleFont allows you to set the font for all of your registered Windows consoles (Windows PowerShell, Windows Terminal, PowerShell, or Command Prompt). It provides tab-autocomplete for the font parameter, listing all of the Nerd Fonts and monospace fonts installed in Windows.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text: Set-ConsoleFont -Font ‘FiraCode Nerd Font’

docs.title: -Font
docs.text:
The name of the font to set for your consoles in Windows.

Type: System.String
DefaultValue: ''
SupportsWildcards: false
Aliases: []
ParameterSets:
- Name: (All)
  Position: 0
  IsRequired: true
  ValueFromPipeline: false
  ValueFromPipelineByPropertyName: false
  ValueFromRemainingArguments: false
DontShow: false
AcceptedValues: []
HelpMessage: ''

docs.text: Set environment variables.

 [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Show an object without its empty properties.

docs.title: __AllParameterSets
docs.text: Show-WithoutEmptyProperty [-Object] <Object> [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: ALIASES
docs.text: This cmdlet has the following aliases, {{Insert list of aliases}}

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: This function shows the properties of an object with all of its empty properties filtered out.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text: Show-WithoutEmptyProperty -Object $Object

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text:
$Desk = [PSCustomObject]@{ Model = ‘PSDesk’ Height = $null Width = $null Colors = @(‘Black’, ‘Gray’) Adjustable = $true } $Object = New-Object -TypeName PSObject -Property $Desk Show-WithoutEmptyProperty -Object $Object

This example creates an object from a hash table and then shows that object’s properties that have values.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 3
docs.text:
Show-WithoutEmptyProperty -Object (Get-Item $HOME)

This example gets the home folder object while invoking the function.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 4
docs.text:
$Object | Show-WithoutEmptyProperty

This example shows how an object can be piped to the function.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 5
docs.text:
Get-ChildItem $HOME | Select-Object -First 1 | Show-WithoutEmptyProperty

This example gets the home folder object and pipes it to the Show-WithoutEmptyProperty function.

docs.title: -Object
docs.text:
The object to show.

Type: System.Object
DefaultValue: ''
SupportsWildcards: false

  Position: 0
  IsRequired: true
  ValueFromPipeline: true
  ValueFromPipelineByPropertyName: false
  ValueFromRemainingArguments: false
DontShow: false
AcceptedValues: []
HelpMessage: ''

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Update all the things!

docs.title: __AllParameterSets
docs.text:
Update-AllTheThings [-SkipModules] [-SkipScripts] [-SkipHelp] [-SkipWinGet] [-IncludeChocolatey]
 [-AcceptPrompts] [-WhatIf] [-Confirm] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: ALIASES
docs.text: This cmdlet has the following aliases, {{Insert list of aliases}}

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: A script to automatically update all PowerShell modules, PowerShell Help, and packages (apt, brew, chocolately, winget).

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Update-AllTheThings

Updates all of the things it can!

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text:
Update-AllTheThings -AcceptPrompts

Updates all of the things and automatically accepts Linux package upgrade prompts.

docs.title: -AcceptPrompts
docs.text:
Automatically accept prompts to install updates in Linux (apt, dnf).
